steps: Wash your hands if possible before touching the wound.
Apply firm pressure with a clean cloth or bandage to stop the bleeding.
Keep the injured part elevated above the heart if possible.

followups.question: Is the bleeding spurting or unusually heavy? (yes/no)

bleeding.escalation: If bleeding does not stop after 10 minutes or is severe, seek emergency medical care.

steps: Call for emergency help immediately if available.
Apply very firm pressure and pack the wound with clean cloth.
If trained and a tourniquet is available, apply it above the wound.
Keep the person calm and monitor breathing.
Cool the burn under cool running water for at least 20 minutes.
Do not apply oil, butter, or toothpaste.
Cover loosely with a clean, non-fluffy cloth.
burns.escalation: Seek medical care for severe burns, burns on face/genitals, or large area burns.

steps: Immobilize the injured area. Do not try to straighten the bone.
Apply a cold pack wrapped in cloth to reduce swelling.
Keep the person still until medical help arrives.
Encourage the person to cough if they can.
If they cannot breathe, cough, or speak: give 5 back blows between the shoulder blades.
If still choking, perform abdominal thrusts (Heimlich maneuver).
choking.escalation: Call emergency services immediately if the person becomes unconscious.

steps: Encourage rest in a cool environment.
Give fluids to prevent dehydration.
Apply a cool damp cloth to the forehead.
fever.escalation: Seek medical attention if fever is very high, persistent, or accompanied by confusion, breathing problems, or seizures.

steps: Drink plenty of safe fluids.
Use Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS) after each episode if available.
Avoid unsafe or spoiled food.
diarrhea.escalation: Seek medical help if diarrhea is severe, bloody, or persistent.

steps: Sip small amounts of clean water or ORS frequently.
Avoid solid food until vomiting stops.
Rest in a comfortable position.
vomiting.escalation: Seek medical help if vomiting persists, contains blood, or causes dehydration.

steps: Drink warm fluids.
Rest in a well-ventilated room.
Avoid smoke and dust.
cough.escalation: Seek medical help if cough lasts more than 2 weeks, produces blood, or is accompanied by breathing difficulty.

steps: Sit the person upright and keep them calm.
Use an inhaler if prescribed.
Loosen tight clothing.
asthma.escalation: Seek urgent medical care if symptoms do not improve within 20 minutes or worsen.

steps: Note symptoms: fever, chills, sweating, headache.
Ensure hydration and rest.
malaria.escalation: Seek medical testing and treatment immediately if malaria is suspected.

steps: Practice deep breathing (inhale 4 seconds, hold 4 seconds, exhale 4 seconds).
Engage in relaxation, prayer, or talking with someone you trust.
stress.escalation: If stress is overwhelming or persistent, seek professional support.

steps: Acknowledge feelings of fear, sadness, or anger.
Talk with trusted people.
Engage in daily routines and safe activities.
trauma.escalation: Seek mental health support if symptoms worsen or interfere with daily life.

steps: Talk with someone you trust about your feelings.
Engage in simple activities you enjoy.
Maintain a routine if possible.
depression.escalation: Seek mental health support if sadness persists for weeks or interferes with life.

steps: Keep the person calm and still.
Immobilize the bitten limb.
Do not cut, suck, or apply ice to the wound.
Wash the wound thoroughly with soap and water for at least 15 minutes.
Apply antiseptic if available.
dog_bite.escalation: Seek urgent medical care for rabies prevention.

steps: Do not rub the eye.
If chemical, rinse gently with clean water.
Cover with a clean cloth.
Sit upright and lean forward.
Pinch the soft part of the nose for 10 minutes.
nosebleed.escalation: Seek medical help if bleeding is heavy or does not stop.

steps: Move the person to a cool shaded place.
Remove excess clothing.
Sponge with cool water and fan.
Move person to a warm place.
Remove wet clothing and cover with blankets.
Give warm drinks if conscious.
Check responsiveness and breathing.
Call for help.
If not breathing, begin CPR: 30 chest compressions, 2 rescue breaths.
Do not induce vomiting unless told by medical professionals.
Try to identify the substance.
Keep the person still.
If conscious, give something sugary (juice, honey, glucose tablets).
Encourage the person to sit or lie down safely.

steps: If heavy bleeding after childbirth, massage the uterus if trained.
Encourage breastfeeding to help the uterus contract.
Keep the baby warm with skin-to-skin contact or blankets.
Ensure exclusive breastfeeding.
Clean the cord with dry care.
newborn_care.escalation: Seek medical care if baby is not feeding, breathing fast, or has fever.
